bibl.title: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Henry Rose Carter, November 7, 1924

div1.p: Rosenau discusses the origins and epidemiology of diseases, and comments on Carter's manuscript.

div1.head: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Henry Rose Carter, November 7, 1924
div1.opener:
Book
Rosenau
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
MEDICAL SCHOOL
DEPARTMENT OF PREVENTIVE MEDICINE AND HYGIENE
Boston, Massachusetts.
November 7, 1924.
Dr. H. R. Carter,
2122 California Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Dr. Carter:
div1.p:
I note with satisfaction your notes on my
notes, which in some instances are almost more noteworthy than
the manuscript itself. I feel rather guilty in causing you so
much trouble. There is no doubt that your conclusions are
justified and convincing and I am sure will carry conviction.
Epidemiology, like history and sociology, must think in world
terms nowadays. I am, you will note, an internationalist. In
several instances, I have been considering the epidemiology of
certain infections in terms of geologic times. Even in recent
years, we have seen examples of diseases that have almost dis-
appeared from civilization to suddenly reappear and become pan-
demic. A good example of this is the plague, which smouldered
in a few outlying endemic and rarely visited localities. It
only had to be carried to a seaport (Hong Kong) to travel to
the four quarters of the globe, and it is now deeply planted.
I think myself that syphilis was not a new disease in the lat-
ter part of the 15th century, but had gradually become atten-
uated as it is now doing before our very eyes, to attain a new
virulence and distribution among a more susceptible population
in a changed world. Things like this might take eons to come
to pass.

In general, an endemic disease means an old
disease which has reached an equilibrium. This is particularly
true with a disease like yellow fever, where the adult popula-
tion is immune and epidemics depend upon susceptible material.
This is a characteristic of yellow fever which adds point to
your thesis, for surely a number of Spaniards could not have
lived & or long in the Tierra Calienta or in Yucatan without suffering
with this infection in epidemic form.

I am very glad that you gave in detail the Mayon
facts of history with the translation. I think it would be a
very great mistake if you took out a single word of this part
of your manuscript.
Again and always my love to you and L-a-u-ra.
